I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Nepal for the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) Road Connectivity 
Project.  The  report  also  describes  a  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Capacity 
Strengthening for Sustainable Road Transport, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The proposed project will improve connectivity in Nepal and between Nepal and its 
neighbors. The main investment is an alternate route in Sunsari and Saptari districts. This will 
create year-round passable conditions along the East–West Highway (EWH), especially across 
the Koshi River. The repair of three feeder roads in the hill areas will improve connectivity 
between villages along this road system and better access to basic services. The project comes 
with gender equality and social inclusion (GESI) plan, and the government staff will be trained 
on road maintenance, planning and project management.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.   Nepal is a landlocked country.  More than 70% of the area is mountainous terrain. Road 
transport is central to economic and social development, accounting for almost 90% of the 
country’s passenger and freight movement. Poor road connectivity is a major constraint for 
Nepal. Its road density is low—14 km per 100 km2 or 0.9 km per 1,000 people. The so-called 
strategic road network (SRN), with a total length of about 14,490 km of national and feeder 
roads, is the core of Nepal’s roads system. It carries most of the country’s road traffic and 
provides linkages to major economic centers and neighboring countries. This network consists 
of three main east–west corridors and several north–south corridors. The east–west corridors 
includes the EWH (1,024 km). This is the main artery in the country and the one with the 
heaviest traffic into the Terai region. The East–West corridors also comprise (i) postal roads 
running in parallel with the EWH along the Indian border to the south; and (ii) the Mid-Hill East–
West Corridor (MHC), a series of feeder roads (1,700 km) that link mid-hill districts and the main 
centers in the hills, including Kathmandu and Pokhara. 
4.   Approximately 32% of the SRN is paved, while 23% is gravel, and 45% is earth. As the 
backbone  of  Nepal’s  national  highway  system,  the  EWH  must  meet  minimum  technical 
standards and be passable all year round. While the EWH is in a reasonable condition, parts of 
the highway, in particular the main Koshi Barrage in Sunsari District, are prone to damage from 
heavy floods and require alternate routes in case of closure. Nepal actively participates in the 
SASEC program. EWH is critical for domestic connectivity, but also key to link it to India.  
5.   Only 6% of the MHC is paved. The government wants to improve the entire 1,700 km 
stretch  into  all-weather  maintainable  standard.  This  will  connect  communities  and  provide 
access to basic services. There is also a need to improve north–south linkages between EWH 
and MHC.  
6.  Nepal’s transport strategy is set out in the Three Year Plan (2010–2013). This is based 
on a Sector Wide Road Program and Priority Investment Plan (2007–2017).2  Key priorities 
                                                 
1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2 The World Bank. 2007. Sector Wide Road Program and Priority Investment Plan. Kathmandu.

2 
 
include (i) connecting the regional centers and all 75 district headquarters, (ii) completing the 
MHC, and (iii) strengthening the road maintenance. The Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and 
Transport (MPIT) is responsible for road network planning and road sector policies. Under MPIT, 
three agencies have responsibilities related to road network management. The Department of 
Roads (DOR) is responsible for network planning, design, construction, and maintenance of the 
SRN. The Department of Transport Management (DOTM) is responsible for vehicle registration 
and renewal, vehicle inspection, overloading control, route permits, and driving licenses. The 
Roads Board Nepal (RBN) is mandated to create a road fund through the collection of road user 
charges. The RBN approves the DOR's annual road maintenance plan and monitors the use of 
funds allocated to it. 
7.  Maintenance work is funded from fuel levies and registration fees. For 2012, $30 million 
were allocated for regular, periodic and recurrent maintenance. This level of funding will need to 
increase in line with the expansion of the road network. While a road asset management system 
is in place, and tolling and performance-based maintenance contracts are in use, improvement 
of both schemes is necessary. An integrated road maintenance scheme needs to be developed. 
There is also a need to improve the collaboration and coordination work by DOR, DOTM and 
RBN.  
8.  The alternate EWH route, connecting to the new bridge over the Koshi River at Chatara,3 
will ensure that the EWH is passable year round. The upgraded feeder roads in the mid-hill 
region will facilitate regionally balanced economic growth. The feeder road in the Indian border 
area  is  one  of  the  key  sections  of  the  SASEC  corridor  (Kakarvitta–Panitanki–Phulbari–
Banglabandha), which connects to NH31 in India and NH5 in Bangladesh. Work in these 
sections will complement work under a SASEC Trade Facilitation Program.4 The project is 
included in the country operations business plan, 2012–2014,5 and the South Asia Regional 
Cooperation Operations Business Plan, 2013–2015.6 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.   The  project  will  improve  local  and  regional  connectivity.  The  outcome  will  be  an 
improved road transport system in eastern Nepal.  
 
C.  Outputs 
10.  The  outputs  will  be  (i)  roads  upgraded  to  all-weather  standard  with  community 
participation  and  (ii)  improved  capacity  of  MPIT  (DOR,  DOTM  and  RBN)  in  road  asset 
management and road maintenance, and enhanced capacity of DOR to deliver gender equality 
and social inclusion following completion of GESI guidelines for the road subsector. These 
outputs will be achieved through the Project and the TA.  
11.  The project will upgrade about 73 km of bypass road and border road along EWH to two-
lane standard and about 114 km of MHC7 to intermediate-lane standard. The road construction

will largely include community participation, as it will create employment for unskilled labors, 
particularly women, in the community. To enhance biodiversity in the project area, the project 
will provide training for the local people to become eco-guardians and to earn income by 
providing accommodation for the tourists. To ensure social inclusiveness of the local people, 
awareness campaigns on road safety, sexually transmitted infection (STI) and human trafficking 
will be conducted. The project will help DOR complete the GESI guidelines for road subsector, 
which will strengthen its capacity to improve gender equality and social inclusion in its future 
operation.  
12.  The TA attached to the Project will strengthen capacity of the DOR, DOTM and RBN in 
road asset management and road maintenance (para 18).

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The executing agency will be the MPIT and the implementing agency will be the DOR. 
The existing project implementation unit, responsible for ongoing ADB-financed projects, will be 
retained  under  the  DOR  to  implement  the  project.  Five  additional  unit  site  offices  will  be 
established, each of which will be led by a project manager. The DOR will recruit a construction 
supervision consultant. Advance contracting has been undertaken. Other readiness filters are in 
place. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in

17.  E-submission of bids will be allowed for national competitive bidding work packages. The 
DOR has previously carried out e-procurement up to the stage of e-submission of bids for 
projects funded domestically and by development partners. This work was efficient and effective 
in enhancing transparency and fair competition. 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
18.  A TA will be provided for strengthening sustainable road maintenance. The objective is 
to improve the capacity of three agencies: the DOR, DOTM, and RBN. The TA has three major 
outputs: (i) an integrated road maintenance scheme, (ii) a road user charge scheme, and (iii)

5 
 
upgraded software for a highway management information system. The TA costs $570,000, of 
which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-other sources). The government will provide the balance. An international consulting firm 
will be recruited in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants to help with this 
work. 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
19.  Based on the feasibility study conducted under the project preparatory TA in 2010, 
detailed design of the five project roads has been prepared.9 The design of road embankment 
and  drainage  structures  has  taken  into  consideration  the  likely  effects  of  climate  change. 
Bioengineering techniques have been adopted as a slope protection measure for the mid-hill 
roads.10 These have been successfully applied in several road projects in Nepal, and the DOR’s 
expertise in this area is recognized. A road safety audit was performed as part of the detailed 
design  and  the  recommendations  were  incorporated  in  the  final  product.  With  bidding 
documents  ready,  advance  actions  have  been  taken  to  ensure  that  the  construction  can 
commence early.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
20.  Economic viability. The benefits of the project will be savings in vehicle operating costs 
and travel time.11 The estimated economic internal rates of return (EIRR) range from 21.7% to 
30.6% for individual project roads. The overall estimated EIRR is 26.4%. The sensitivity analysis 
further confirms the robustness of economic viability. When the construction costs increase by 
10% or the traffic volume decreases by 10%, the EIRR is still above 12%. 
 
21.  In addition, the project will bring significant benefits to overall regional development. 
Even with the closure of Koshi Bridge during heavy flooding and/or landslides, transport along 
the EWH would not be disrupted. Local communities will benefit from construction employment. 
After  project  completion,  they  will  have  access  to  markets  which  will  result  in  increased 
household income. The benefits accrued from savings in vehicle operating costs will be passed 
on to the poor through lower freight rates, lower passenger fares, and time savings. Households 
in remote areas will benefit from an increase in the availability of goods and a decrease in prices.  
 
22.   Financial  sustainability.  Recurrent  costs  on  project  roads  will  decrease  after  the 
construction is completed. In the long term, incremental recurrent costs are estimated at 7% of 
the current DOR maintenance budget, and less than 1% of the overall annual DOR budget. 
Maintenance will be required after 2018. By then, the government is committed to doing this. 
 
C.  Governance 
23.  Institutional. The DOR has a good track record of implementing ADB-financed projects. 
It has sufficient capacity. This capacity is further increased by a World Bank project and an

ongoing ADB TA.12 The latter includes training for feasibility studies and practices in contract 
management and quality assurance.13  
 
24.  Financial  management. A financial management assessment was carried out. The 
DOR has developed capacity in financial accounting and ADB disbursement procedures. The 
DOR  project  directorate  will  have  a  qualified  chief  project  accountant  and  two  assistant 
accountants. The DOR will also establish and maintain separate project records and accounts 
to identify the financing resources received and expenditures made under the project, ensuring 
an adequate audit trail. The government's Office of the Auditor General will annually audit the 
project  accounts  and  related  financial  statements  in  accordance  with  international  auditing 
standards.  To  further  minimize  risks,  ADB's  direct  payment  procedure  will  be  used  for 
substantial disbursements for works, goods, and consulting services. 
 
25.   Procurement  and  anticorruption.  The  government  has  promulgated  the  Public 
Procurement  Act  (2007)  and  Public  Procurement  Regulations  (2007),  both  of  which  are 
generally acceptable to ADB and encompass best international procurement practices. The 
Public Procurement Monitoring Office has been assigned as the national procurement oversight 
body under the Office of the Prime Minister and Council of Ministers. The government will 
publish  information  on  the  project  on  DOR’s  website,  including  business  opportunities 
associated with the project, and information on procurement of goods, works, and consulting 
services. E-submission of bids which has substantially increased transparency and fairness in 
bidding competition of in the previous ADB road project will be adopted.14 
 
26.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy was explained to and discussed with the government. The 
specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
27.  Poverty reduction and social impact. The Nepal Living Standard Survey conducted by 
the Central Bureau of Statistics during 1995–2011 revealed a substantial decrease in poverty 
over recent years. However, the overall poverty situation in Nepal still remains serious. More 
than 25% of the population lives below the government poverty line of NRs19,261 (about $246) 
per year. Rural poverty is almost twice as high as urban poverty. Poverty incidence is 34%–57% 
in  project-affected  rural  districts,  compared  with  25%  nationally.  In  the  project  districts  of 
Ramechhap, Khotang, Sunsari, Udayapur, Bhojpur, Saptari, and Jhapa, a large proportion of 
the population is indigenous. Most of these districts are also food insecure. Difficulties with 
transport limit people’s ability to take their agricultural products to markets. The results of 
household surveys and focus group discussions conducted as part of the poverty and social 
assessment indicate that the project will increase economic and employment opportunities, as 
well as, access to markets, production centers, and public and social services.  
 
28.  Gender. A gender analysis highlights the type of benefits accruing from road projects. 
Focus group discussions with women in the project areas indicate that improved access to

markets  and  basic  services  will  improve  significantly  health  and  education  outcomes, 
particularly among women and children. Most local women, who currently travel by foot on 
earthen tracks that are impassable during the rainy season, will have safer, faster, and more 
comfortable access once the investments are completed. Cash-strapped subsistence farmers, 
including  women,  will  benefit  from  other  activities  such  as  short-term  employment  in  road 
construction and maintenance. 
 
29.  A GESI plan incorporates the following gender mainstreaming features:  
(i)  At least 50% of those trained and engaged in bioengineering for slope protection 
works  will  be  women  from  local  communities. 15  This  will  be  facilitated  by 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs).  
(ii)  At least 50% of those engaged in compensatory afforestation will be women. This 
will be conducted in a partnership between community forest users and NGOs 
(footnote 15). 
(iii)  At  least  40%  of  those  trained  and  engaged  as  eco-guardians  will  be  women 
(footnote 15).  
(iv)  At least 40% of those participating in road safety awareness sessions carried out 
for affected communities in local languages will be women.  
(v)  At  least  50%  of  those  participating  in  sexually  transmitted  infection  (STI)  and 
human trafficking awareness campaigns will be women. 
 
30.  The bidding documents have clauses to ensure that all civil work contractors comply with 
labor laws by not employing child labor; encouraging employment of the poor (particularly 
women); and paying the same wage to men and women for work of equal value. Special 
provisions for vulnerable households—including those headed by women—are provided in the 
combined indigenous people and resettlement plans. A full time national GESI consultant will be 
placed  in  DOR.  An  international  GESI  consultant  will  assist  DOR  finalize  guidelines  for 
mainstreaming GESI in the road sector. An NGO will carry out livelihood enhancement and 
awareness programs on road safety, STIs, and human trafficking.  
  
31.  HIV and human trafficking. The National Center for AIDS and Sexually Transmitted 
Disease  Control  under  the  Ministry  of  Health  and  Population  coordinates  activities  by 
stakeholders  committed  under  the  National  AIDS  Strategy,  2006–2011.16 This  emphasizes 
prevention as the most effective response. Anti-human trafficking activities are coordinated by 
the Ministry of Women, Children, and Social Welfare. A large amount of information and print 
material on human trafficking has been developed with the support of the United States Agency 
for International Development, which now be reproduced for use in project areas. The project 
incorporates measures to mitigate HIV risks by having NGOs undertake awareness programs in 
the corridors of influence. The contractors will carry out STI and human trafficking awareness for 
their laborers at work sites, which will be monitored by the construction supervision consultant 
(CSC). 
 
E.  Safeguards 
32.   Social  and  environmental  impacts  have  been  assessed  (and  will  be  mitigated)  in 
accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and government regulations and 
policies. All safeguard aspects (environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples) 
are  classified  as  category  A.  The  combined  indigenous  peoples  and  resettlement  plans, 
                                                 
15 Subject to availability of women volunteers in the project areas. 
16 National Center of AIDS and STD Control. 2011. National HIV/AIDS Strategy. Kathmandu.

8 
 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) reports, and initial environmental examination (IEE) 
reports  prepared  under  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  have  been  reviewed, 
updated and disclosed. The DOR has sufficient capacity in implementing environment and 
social safeguard plans. This has been demonstrated in the previous ADB projects. 
 
 33.   Environment. The alternate route for EWH falls under category A. It traverses an 
elephant corridor and also passes through the buffer zone of the Koshi Tappu Wildlife Reserve, 
which is a Ramsar site.17 The potential adverse impacts identified are disturbance of elephant 
movement mainly due to increased traffic from the improved road and worsening of the existing 
human–wildlife  conflicts  and  wildlife  disturbance  in  the  project  area.  The  environmental 
management plan (EMP), which is a key part of the contractor’s bidding documents, includes 
measures to address adverse impacts during all stages of project. Another component of the 
EMP is focused on a combination of biodiversity enhancement and gender-inclusive activities. 
This  will  be  implemented  by  a  local  NGO  in  collaboration  with  existing  conservation  and 
livelihood projects in the project area. Consultations have been carried out at various stages of 
project  development  and  advice  was  sought  from  local  communities,  the  wildlife  reserve’s 
management, government agencies, and local and international NGOs. The EIA report was 
prepared and disclosed on the ADB website on 23 November 2012.   
 
34.  The four feeder roads to be upgraded, (Leguwaghat–Bhojpur, Halesi–Diktel, Mechipul–
Birtamod, and Manthali–Ramechhap) are classified under category B. They do not fall inside or 
near protected areas or critical habitats. Most impacts from these roads are likely to occur 
during  construction,  and  are  associated  with  earth  movement,  ground  shaping,  heavy 
equipment operation, and possible landslide and erosion. Appropriate mitigation measures are 
included in the respective EMPs, which will also feature in contract bidding documents. Public 
consultations have been conducted with local communities and government agencies during 
preparation of the IEE reports. The reports have been disclosed on the ADB website as required 
by the Safeguard Policy Statement.  
 
35.  The DOR project directorate will have an environmental focal person to coordinate and 
oversee  proper  implementation  of  all  environment  safeguards.  Technical  support  will  be 
provided  by  the  Geo-Environment  and  Social  Unit  (GESU),  which  is  responsible  for 
implementing and monitoring social and environment safeguards for all DOR projects. The 
GESU has received capacity building assistance from various international agencies, including 
ADB. Its team is capable and experienced. The CSC team includes an environmental expert 
that will supervise and guide the implementation of the EMPs by the contractor. Biodiversity 
enhancement activities for the EWH road components will be implemented by a local NGO (in 
close collaboration with the local Forestry Department, and the Department of National Parks 
and Wildlife Conservation). A training and coordination workshop will be conducted before 
project implementation to clarify the roles and responsibilities of all project stakeholders. Semi-
annual environmental monitoring reports for all the project roads will be prepared for disclosure 
on the ADB website in compliance with the Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
36.  The upgrading of the alternate EWH route is a climate change adaptation measure. The 
existing EWH becomes inaccessible due to breaching of the Koshi Barrage by excess water 
and silt being brought down to the Terai from the mountains. With climate change and an 
increase in glacial melting at the headwaters of the Koshi River, this problem is expected to 
become worse. Improvement of the existing EWH would be very expensive. The alternate road 
                                                 
17 The Ramsar Convention (The Convention on Wetlands of International Importance, especially as Waterfowl 
Habitat) is an international treaty for the conservation and sustainable utilization of wetlands.

9 
 
is located north of the existing EWH and the Koshi Barrage. The terrain in the project area is 
hilly and the deep gorge and steep slope allows the excess water to flow southward, hence the 
likelihood of floods and damage to the road and Chatara Bridge is less. The alternate route is 
less  vulnerable  to climate  change.  The  engineering  design  of  the project  roads  has  been 
prepared  taking  into  account  climate  change  considerations  (temperature  and  rainfall). 
Measures taken include raising road embankments and bridge heights, strengthening road 
surfaces, improving drainage structures, and bioengineering on unstable slopes and erosion-
prone areas. 
 
37.  Involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The project design minimizes land 
acquisition and involuntary resettlement while adopting the most feasible technical features. A 
full census of the areas was conducted. Combined indigenous peoples and resettlement plans 
have been prepared for three of the project roads and resettlement due diligence reports have 
been prepared for two others in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, the Land 
Acquisition Act 1977, and other national laws and regulations. 
 
38.  The project will result in significant land acquisition and resettlement. A total of 76.49 
hectares of private land will be acquired. Major impacts will be on 1,982 households, 1,383 of 
which will be physically displaced. Thus, 11,181 people will be affected. The total resettlement 
budget for the project is $11.8 million. Compensation rates for the loss of land and structures, 
relocation assistance, income restoration assistance, and additional support for vulnerable and 
indigenous groups are provided in the entitlement matrix. The combined plans outline the 
compensation entitlements. These have been endorsed by the MPIT and an adequate budget 
has been allocated. Consultation and information disclosure were undertaken with (i) people to 
be displaced, (ii) indigenous peoples’ households in the project areas and their leaders, and (iii) 
the public through the ADB website. If any changes, additional land requirements, or involuntary 
resettlement impacts are identified, a new or updated resettlement plan will be prepared or 
modified according to the laws referred to in the resettlement plan. ADB’s approval will be 
obtained before further implementation of the relevant section of the project roads can take 
place. The DOR project directorate will have a resettlement and safeguards focal person to 
coordinate and oversee proper implementation of the combined plans. Technical support will be 
provided  by  GESU.  The  CSC  team  will  include  a  resettlement  expert  that  will  guide  and 
supervise implementation of the combined plans. The DOR will submit the monitoring reports to 
ADB on a semiannual basis. 
 
39.  The government has declared 59 groups as indigenous peoples, or “Janjatis” as they are 
commonly known, comprising about 37.2% of Nepal’s population. Indigenous peoples make up 
about 39% of the project district populations and 28% of the total household populations in the 
road influence areas. Consultations with indigenous groups and their leaders were conducted 
as  part  of  the  social  impact  assessment,  and  the  census  survey.  This  was  done  in  an 
atmosphere  free  of  coercion  and  in  a  culturally  sensitive  manner.  This  was  to  ensure  a 
comprehensive perspective on the project and its impacts, to ascertain community responses 
and their needs and demands from the project, to estimate the losses they would suffer, and to 
take steps to mitigate those losses. This process is to make sure that indigenous peoples will 
not be affected more than the rest of the population and will have culturally appropriate benefits 
from the socioeconomic opportunities created by the project. The project will not have adverse 
impacts on the identity, culture, and customary livelihoods of the indigenous people.

10 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
40.  The integrated benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. Major risks and 
mitigating measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan, 
as summarized in Table 4.18 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Procurement: Oversight and guidance on up-to-date  The Public Procurement Monitoring Office to 
technical guidelines and manuals on procurement  provide oversight  
Procurement and anticorruption: Collusion and  Adopting  e-submission  for  national  competitive 
intimidation  bidding 
Procurement and anticorruption: Disclosure of  DOR to provide project information for business 
information  opportunity on its website 
Anticorruption: Awareness and deterrence  DOR  to  appoint  certified  auditor  to  conduct 
technical audit 
Safeguard compliance  Full compliance with ADB safeguard requirements 
is required prior to construction 
Implementation delay  Advance actions  
Implementation environment  Affected people are included in decision making. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
41.  The  government  and  the  MPIT  assure  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  will 
conform with all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption, safeguards, 
gender,  procurement,  and  disbursement  (as  described  in  detail  in  the  PAM  and  loan 
documents).  
 
42.  The government and the MPIT have agreed with ADB on various covenants. These are 
included in the loan agreement. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION  
43.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan will comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR49,682,000 to Nepal for the South Asia Subregional Economic 
Cooperation Road Connectivity Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest 
charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; 
for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions 
as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to 
the Board. 
 
 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
